description:
Scenario: While launching an instance with a key-pair specified, even if the key-pair injection fails, the instance comes up active and running.

Expected Behavior: The instance should go into error state like vm_state='error', task_state='metadata_injection', power_state=0.

Actual Behavior: Instance comes up active and running.

Branch: master

If data injection fails, user is unable to log-in (ssh) to the instance using the key-pair. If there is a spec or reference that clarifies this behavior, please share the reference.
title: Instance creation should fail if key injection fails

comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~unmesh-gurjar

comments.content:
Although it is possible to change the administrator password for an instance by performing the ‘changePassword’ action, the support is available in Xen but not in KVM. 
I am therefore inclined towards having the instance creation fail if key-pair injection fails.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~unmesh-gurjar

comments.content:
I disagree.

Keypair injection is for developer convenience.  The guest can still set up keypairs via the metadata server via cloud_init. In general we lean towards not messing with guest instances, so it should be the responsibility of the guest to setup keypairs.  In fact, keypair injection should be optional and I would expect most cloud providers to turn it off.

By the way, libvirt can try to inject passwords as well via the config option:

libvirt_inject_password=true
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~vishvananda

comments.content:
I agree that key injection should not be fatal.
Only user specified file injection failure is fatal at present.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~p-draigbrady
